It isn&rsquot about a second referendum and giving people a say.&ldquoBecause we&rsquove had the referendum, we&rsquove had a Brexit general election since and we need to respect that result.&ldquoAll this is about is derailing Brexit and not allowing it to happen.Asked if she was &ldquoconcerned about criminality behind the referendum campaign, she replied: &ldquoLook, in lots of elections and lots of referendums&nbspthere&rsquos&nbspcomplaints made about various&hellipBrexit news: Alastair Campbell shut down by Brexiteer Maria Caulfield over second Brexit referendum (Image: UK PARLIAMENT&bull)At this point, the Tory MP was interrupted by both Mr Campbell and radio host William Crawley pointing out the question was about &ldquocriminality and not complaints.But Ms Caulfield snapped back immediately. She blasted: &ldquoLet me finish!&ldquoThat is investigated by the Electoral Commission, which has happened in this case, she added.&ldquoAnd when the Electoral Commission has concerns that criminal activities have happened, they report that to the police and that is being investigated.&nbspThat happens in lots of elections.The former Labour Director of Communications believes there are growing calls in the UK for another&nbspBrexit&nbspvote because the situation is now completely different to two years ago.He said:&nbsp&ldquoThere is a sense of people whether they voted Remain or Leave thinking this is just a mess and it is not going well.&ldquoThe negotiations are going badly, the promises that were made are not being kept, things that we were told were going to happen aren&rsquot happening, things that we were told weren&rsquot going to happen are happening.&ldquoThe country is starting to think well hold on a minute this is not quite what we thought was going to happen and there is a desperation amongst Brexiteers because I think they worry that if there was a Peoples Vote on the outcome of the negotiations that it would be rejected, they are right to worry.

title: Homebase store closures shops shut job losses Homebase news high street
story: Homebase is set to shut 42 DIY stores (Image: HOMEBASE)The DIY chain is closing the stores through a Company Voluntary Agreement (CVA), a procedure used by struggling firms to shut under-performing shops.Restructuring experts at Alvarez &amp Marsal will carry out the CVA, which will require the support of landlords.An official announcement from the company is due later today.The latest restructuring comes on top of a store closure programme which began in February.                1000 jobs at risk as Homebase closes 60 stores                B&ampQ and Homebase could PULL Roundup from shelvesHomebase has already closed 17 branches this year and the business has also axed 303 jobs at its head office in Milton Keynes.There could be resistance to the CVA proposals with commercial landlords complaining the procedure leaves them out-of-pocket.CVAs have been recently used by a host of struggling retailers including New Look, Carpetright and Mothercare.The Homebase business was sold for &pound1 earlier this year by its former Australian owner Wesfarmers to retail turnaround specialist Hilco.Homebase was sold for &pound1 earlier this year (Image: HOMEBASE)Wesfarmers bought the chain for for &pound340 million in 2016.Wesfarmers is known for its Bunnings chain in Australia, and attempted to import the home improvement brand to the UK by converting a host of Homebase stores into the Bunnings format but the strategy ended in disaster.Prior to the Hilco takeover, Homebase had 250 stores at its peak and 12,000 staff.                Tech can save town centres                Banks in line of fire over high street crisisHannah Maundrell, Editor in Chief of money, said: &ldquoIt&rsquos undoubtedly distressing news for employees of Homebase and their families, especially those who are yet to find out their fate.&ldquoHomebase staff have been left in limbo after many jobs have already been cut this year. Those who fear they could lose their jobs should hope for the best but prepare for the worst.&ldquoNow is the time to check what redundancy rights you have and dig out any income or mortgage protection policies you hold just in case.&ldquoSadly this isn&rsquot the beginning of redundancies in the retail sector this year and I doubt it will be the end. Shoppers habits are changing, purse strings are tightening and our reluctance to pay full price becomes more problematic for stores.Retail expert Stuart McClure, co-founder of LovetheSales &nbspsaid: The announcement of Homebase store closures is unsurprising.&ldquoThey've had problems for a while, as has been documented in the press.&ldquoThese problems have been compounded by competing retailers offering big price reductions in Home and Garden which has lured away shoppers looking for better deals.

title: unemployment figures lowest level 40 years
story: Unemployment fell by 65,000 between April and June to 1.36 million (Image: )During the same time frame, productivity was up by 0.4 percent, but wage growth remained unchanged.The figures, from the Office for National Statistics (ONS), also showed average weekly earnings, excluding bonuses, rose by 2.7 percent.Real wages grew by just 0.4 percent, slightly down from last month's figure of 0.5 percent.The unemployment rate was 4 percent, a figure which is down from the 4.2 percent recorded the previous month.                Jobs bonanza as economy surges after Brexit vote                Labour&rsquos &lsquomoney for NOTHING&rsquo welfare plan would ENCOURAGE unemploymentSenior ONS statistician Matt Hughes said: The number of people in work has continued to edge ahead.The unemployment rate is now at its lowest since the winter of 1974-75.Commenting on the latest ONS numbers, Tej Parikh, senior economist at the Institute of Directors, said: The enduring desire for businesses to hire and create new positions is without doubt a sign of strength in the face of unprecedented economic uncertainty.Yet with the pool of available workers shrinking at a rapid speed, particularly given flagging immigration numbers, firms are finding it harder to recruit the staff they need.Unemployment is the lowest for more than 40 years (Image: )Under any normal circumstances this would mean pay packets should rise markedly as corporates compete for workers, but we shouldn't hold our breath.Many businesses are still struggling to find the margins to notably boost salaries given sky-high business rates, the rise in national living wage, and subdued productivity growth.Unemployment in the regions between April and June was (region, total unemployed, change on quarter, unemployment rate)&bull North East: 54,000, minus 10,000, 4.3 percent&bull North West: 148,000, minus 6,000, 4.1 percent&bull Yorkshire and the Humber: 114,000, minus 12,000, 4.2 percent                UK is HAPPIER than ever as record low unemployment boost happiness

story: A remote island parish is seeking a new church minister (Image: SWNS)With its white sand beaches and crystal clear waters, the &ldquounique opportunity on Tiree could be seen as heaven sent.The tiny Hebridean isle &ndash population 650 &ndash is known as the &ldquosunshine isle for its good weather, according to the Church of Scotland.The successful applicant will hold services in Tiree&rsquos only church and enjoy jaw-dropping views to the islands of Mull and Iona from the clergy house that comes with the job.&ldquoWe seek a minister who finds that their heart resonates with this island and this community, states an advert for the position. The last permanent minister on Tiree left two years ago.The congregation on the island, which is 30 miles square, has been actively seeking a new minister for the past year. Last month they joined Twitter to help find the right person.Jo Bennett, clerk of the congregation&rsquos nominating committee, said Tiree was &ldquoa place where the distance between heaven and earth collapses... but very much a working community.He added: &ldquoA minister here has the chance to see the impact of the work they do and be the focal point for the community.

story: Tropical storm Leepi: Strong winds and heavy rain will reach southern Japan today (Image: HURRICANEZONE)Tropical storm Leepi is currently in the West Pacific, as the Japanese prepares for yet another windy night.Strong winds and heavy rain will reach eastern Shikoku and western Kyushu as winds increase.Storm Leepi will hit a limited area of Japan due to its small size, but gusty winds and downpours will still be felt in most of southern Japan.Kyushu will be hit the hardest, according to AccuWeather forecasters.                Japan weather: Why is Japan being battered by natural disasters?                Typhoon Yagi forces thousands to evacuate Philippines decimatedTravel disruptions and local flooding are the most likely impacts in Shikoku.There is an increased risk for mudslides and flooding, and the wind may cause tree damage and power outages.Flooding and mudslides are also a concern across western and northern Honshu and Hokkaido.Further into the week the storm will likely dissipate, and weaken before it spreads to the rest of the country.Tropical storm Leepi: The storm is currently in the West Pacific (Image: AccuWeather)Tropical storm Leepi will then interact with a larger storm system moving in the Pacific ocean outside Japan.Travel disruptions are expected and may last until Wednesday morning, before conditions improve.AccuWeather senior meteorologist, Eric Leister says the unsettled weather could also impact the Ryukyu Islands and China.He added: &ldquoA large area of unsettled weather across the southern Ryukyu Islands could develop into a new tropical system and impact the Ryukyu Islands and eastern China later this week. title: expected better from brad pitt and angelina jolie
story: Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie were the caring, sharing, rainbow family that was going to last for ever and ever.Somewhere down the line this relationship buckled, fractured and has now imploded into a bitter legal fight that boiled over in court this week.I expected better of these two.Despite the fact Brad dumped his girl-next-door first wife, Jennifer Aniston, for his sexy, smouldering Mr &amp Mrs Smith co-star Angelina in 2005, I really thought “Brangelina” would go the distance.In the unlikely event the fairy-tale romance turned sour, I believed they would handle the whole thing with dignity and respect for one another.After all, they have six children together and seemed the kind of parents, who would not want to drag their kids through a messy divorce case or custody battle. Well, I was wrong about the messy divorce.Bam! This week Angelina claimed that Brad wasn’t paying her enough child support.Kapow! He hit back that he has coughed up over £7million since they first split over 18 months ago.Sock! Angelina then put the boot in by saying that most of the money was just a loan that she’s having to pay back with interest.Wham! He claims she wants to manipulate the media into branding him a deadbeat dad.It once again proves that no one knows what’s going on inside someone else’s marriage.It might look perfect bliss on the outside, but we have no idea what tense battles are being fought on a daily basis behind closed doors.Despite us all being spoon-fed stories of their perfect relationship over the years, and shown photos of their wedding when the children drew pictures on Angelina’s beautiful white dress, it appears that this relationship has been on the rocks for quite some time.Brad’s friends claim she is fired up with anger over the custody battle and doesn’t want the children to have any sort of relationship with their father.They have slammed her for going public instead of having the divorce hammered out in front of a private judge.Her friends counterclaim that he drank too much and was “rough” with one of the children, thought to be Maddox, the eldest, while they were on a private plane.He was cleared of any wrongdoing, but mud sticks and this was highly damaging as well as deeply distressing for Brad.These two extremely gifted, pampered, beautiful people might have met on a movie set and become infatuated with each other, but this is not a film.This is real life and there are six bewildered youngsters caught up in the eye of the storm.There’s the aforementioned Maddox, 17, then Pax, 14, Zahara, 13, Shiloh, 12, and ten-year-old twins Vivienne and Knox.Shiloh and the twins are the biological children of Brad and Angelina, but they have all been brought up to think of themselves as full brothers and sisters, and just one big family.So it must now be extremely unsettling for them to see all the news reports about custody fights and money squabbles, and to have witnessed friends of their parents forced into taking sides.I have no idea whether the children witnessed any arguments or screaming matches between their parents, but there surely must have been an uncomfortable atmosphere at home in the months before the split.The poor, wee children actually have their own psychiatrists that Brad’s friends claim he pays for.And they have round-the-clock bodyguards available.As with so many splits, money has reared its ugly head, and despite their enormous wealth (it’s estimated that Brad is worth £202million and that Angelina has a personal fortune of £125million) it would appear that it’s all coming down to cold, hard cash.We are a long, long way from the heady Brangelina days when they were the world’s sexiest couple and couldn’t keep their hands off each other.Sadly, most white-hot affairs tend to fizzle out when domesticity kicks in and you need to change nappies and wipe snot from little faces.Even with a team of nannies, six children running around is probably one of the biggest passion killers of all time.So, it’s a real shame that Brad and Angelina couldn’t make it work, but sadder still that their dirty washing is being aired for all the world to see.But theirs is not the only love story to turn rancid . . .ROMEO and Juliet ended in tragedy at the end of Gone With The Wind, Rhett tells Scarlett that he doesn’t give a damn about her reality TV romances rarely last beyond the first glossy magazine spread.I’M not in the least bit surprised that doctors don’t trust us to tell the truth when it comes to how much booze we guzzle.Apparently they nod wisely when we solemnly declare that we have but one small sherry on a Sunday night while watching Songs of Praise, and then they simply double whatever we say or put down a number that seems most likely.New info this week says that just 40 per cent of patients tell the truth to their GPs when it comes to how much they drink every week.Frankly, I’m astonished the figure is that high.Most of us play down our booze intake and exaggerate the amount of exercise we do, but even as we are telling such huge porkies, we all know in our hearts that our doctors aren’t the least bit fooled.We want them to think we are model citizens and that our bodies are temples, but in the long run we need to tell the truth so we can get a proper diagnosis and treatment.And always bear in mind you can’t kid a kidder.There are lots of doctors who overindulge and they know all the tricks and cover-ups.IT’S the final episode of The Handmaid’s Tale tomorrow night, and I will be watching from behind the sofa to find out the fate of our heroine June.She inhabits a world where women have no rights, and handmaids are ritually raped, mutilated and even killed.It’s not easy viewing, but Elisabeth Moss has been mesmerising throughout as June, whose first child was ripped from her arms, and whose newborn baby was also taken away from her.I’m bracing myself for an emotional rollercoaster and Miss Moss should clear her sideboard for a slew of awards.The Handmaid’s Tale, Sunday, Channel 4, 9pm.WHAT sad news to discover that Margot Kidder, who shone so very brightly as the feisty and fiercely intelligent Lois Lane in the original Superman movies, died by suicide.Margot’s death happened back in May, but it was revealed this week that she died as a rfesult of a “self-inflicted drug and alcohol overdose”.The 69-year-old suffered from depression and other mental health issues, which became worse after a car accident in 1990 left her wheelchair-bound for almost two years and facing mounting debts.She had a very tough time but she tried hard to sort out her life and cope with her illness.We should remember her in her heyday.I loved the fact she wasn’t a conventional glamour puss at a time when any actress playing the “love interest” in an action movie was usually a busty blonde doing little more than squeaking and waiting to be rescued.Lois Lane was a kick-ass reporter who adored Superman but also made fun of him during four movies between 1978 and 1987.Those films had real heart and soul and – if you ignore the rather wobbly special effects – are far more entertaining than many of the over-long, over-loud and rather self-important superhero movies of today.I’M no fan of his, but I don’t think Boris Johnson should be forced to apologise for likening woman who wear burkas to letter boxes.It’s his opinion.You very well might disagree, but getting him to say sorry won’t make him stop thinking such thoughts.He will just stop writing and uttering that particular view in public and instead will voice it in private.And that, in my opinion, is far more dangerous.GOT a story? RING The Sun on 0207 782 4104 or WHATSAPP on 07423720250 title: karren brady column self harm
story: New research reveals that the number of girls aged 13 to 16 reporting self-harm to GPs has increased by 68 per cent over just three years.It’s a staggering rise — and that is just the reported cases.Given that self-harm tends to be a solitary pursuit, I think it’s realistic to assume that there are many, many more unreported cases.Self-harm among young people aged ten to 19 is three times more common among girls than boys. Bearing in mind that those who self-harm are at much greater risk of suicide, this is not a problem to be taken lightly.For some young people the act of cutting, or otherwise inflicting pain on themselves, is a way of relieving — albeit temporarily — mental pain and torment by converting it into something more visible and tangible.It’s a way of relieving tension and an attempt to clarify a confusing mental swirl into something that is easier to understand in its simplicity. It’s also a way of punishing yourself.So why the sudden, huge, increase in girls taking this path?Psychiatrists commenting on the research blamed a combination of academic stresses and body-image issues triggered by the use of social media.There’s no doubt that social media, which barely existed ten years ago, has, along with all the good stuff, brought with it a whole new set of pressures.Women’s appearances have always been scrutinised, but that unique equation of the selfie generation plus Photoshop plus the sheer variety of ways to propel your image out into the world has created a series of impossible standards.It’s also created a whole generation that is convinced that everything is going brilliantly for everyone else.When teenagers look at their friend’s social media feeds they see apparently perfect lives, bodies, homes and jobs.And then they feel inadequate.There are other pressures: Pressure to do well in exams have amazing friendships and be brilliantly successful. And, for some people, the relief to those pressures is to hurt themselves, which is surely the saddest and one of the most difficult problems any parent can deal with.After all, it’s our natural instinct to protect our children from harm. But what can we do when the harm comes from within themselves?All teenage kids have intensely difficult phases. And the pressures at school can feel unbearable.If someone doesn’t like you, it feels like the end of the world. If you fail an exam you can feel doomed to failure. School feels like it will never end.Our job is to try to help our children get perspective.Despite the downsides of excessive social media being well documented, it seems that most young people would rather end up with mental health problems than give it up. So maybe they need a helping hand.We need to talk more to our kids about the reality of social media — and limit their time on it.And we need to coax them out of their screen-sized comfort zone.One of the best things kids can do is some volunteering.That way they can meet kids from different backgrounds and people with real problems — such as children born with disabilities who are still making the most of their life.Sport is also brilliant for getting kids to enjoy being part of something bigger than their bedroom, and for celebrating their bodies for what they can do rather than what they look like.The big question is, how can we get them to talk about their feelings, instead of engraving them into their skin until they draw blood?Be kind, patient but determined and, most importantly, we need to talk to our children, ask them how they are feeling — and listen to the answers without judgment.If they won’t talk to you, find someone else they can talk to, either a family friend or even a counsellor if you’re worried about self-harm.But the Government also needs to invest more money into care.Less than one per cent of the NHS budget is spent on children’s mental health, and most of that is on acute care rather than preventative or early intervention services.That needs to change.Most of all, we need to accept that there is a problem and find ways to address it. Because if we don’t, things are going to get much, much worse.SURELY only those with the hardest of hearts could complain about the affection shown by Zara and Mike Tindall, who are frequently photographed kissing, hugging and looking generally happy and totally loved-up.Given they have survived challenging personal losses and have two young children, it’s pretty much a miracle they are so happy.How could anyone wish them anything but well?DID you see the Kardashian and Jenner sisters at Kylie Jenner’s 21st birthday party?What is most striking – other than them all being drop-dead gorgeous, of course – is that they each have totally different body types.I guess what they DO have in common is an unlimited budget for personal trainers and chefs . . . plus the fact that looking this good is their full-time job.His crime was horrific and he deserved to be dealt with.His punishment was to be beheaded and his body crucified and displayed in Mecca.A beheading and crucifixion in this century?There are instances when I do believe that the death penalty is just, but this method is just barbaric.THE latest advice from fertility specialists to women who want to “delay motherhood” is for them to freeze their eggs in their early twenties.At the moment, the vast majority of women who go through the procedure do so in their late thirties – by which time they have little chance of success. But who is going to freeze their eggs in their twenties?I was fortunate to meet the right man in my twenties – and had children once I was married because I wanted to have a family.But plenty of women don’t meet the right partner that early in life, or simply don’t want to have children until they are older.One reason for that is that they want to have a career – and they know babies can seriously damage their chances of promotion or even a pay rise.But the solution is not for women to freeze their eggs.The real solution is a shift in the division of labour between mothers and fathers.So long as the children are not the sole responsibility of just one person in the family, things can work well.If both partners are equally involved, nobody has to totally compromise their life and put their career on hold.As things stand, no wonder women are putting off motherhood. But if more men pulled their weight, maybe women wouldn’t have to worry about freezing their eggs.WHEN you look at photos of the 200 travellers who have descended on the village of Long Ditton in Surrey, you can see why local police sparked fury by telling residents who want to evict them to have empathy instead.The police force tweeted: “Consider for a second how upsetting it would be, being uprooted every few days.”But the photos show piles of rubbish and damaged property.In one, a child is sitting on an adult’s lap while he drives a car around the village green. And I dread to think about the specifics of the toilet situation.What is needed is not empathy but police action.SOME high-profile, wealthy parents – such as Sting, Elton John and Simon Cowell – make a point of saying they won’t leave their fortunes to their children for fear it will ruin their lives.Location, Location, Location presenter Kirstie Allsopp has taken a different tack.She says she will leave her £16million fortune to her two sons . . . IF they get a job.I applaud the sentiment. But if you really want your children to develop a work ethic, rather than relying on inherited income, isn’t the key not to tell your kids – and the whole world – in a national newspaper?Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: government hiking fuel duty
story: Britain’s motorists already get a raw deal at the petrol pump, with fuel duty among the highest in the world.Why should they be hammered further to help bankroll the £20billion NHS splurge?A hike will make people poorer, take cash out of the economy and stoke inflation. Low-paid workers, who need their cars and vans for work, will be unfairly hit.So will ordinary, hard-pressed families, who already have to budget to fill up so they can take their kids to school and transport their weekly supermarket shop.In other words, it will unfairly impact the “Just About Managings” who Theresa May once claimed she would strive to protect.Philip Hammond might regard drivers as a convenient cash cow to fill the Treasury’s coffers.But he should resist clobbering them for a quick cash injection. Targeting those struggling is political cowardice.Voters won’t forgive him.ORDINARY Brits back Boris Johnson.His joke about Muslim women wearing the full black robe looking like “letterboxes” and “bank robbers” has been portrayed as an affront.But away from all the Twitter outrage, the former Foreign Secretary is in step with public opinion.Meanwhile, Jeremy Corbyn continues to shame Labour with his anti-Semitism.Of course, just as we are free to debate the burka, people are free to debate the Israel-Palestine conflict.But a politician with aspirations to run the country should not be laying wreaths for terror leaders.Corbyn believes Israel is the ultimate malevolent force, a racist imperial outpost, causing the world’s ills at the behest of America and Britain. How many traditional Labour voters today share his worldview?It is Boris, derided by his enemies as an Etonian toff, who has his finger on the nation’s pulse and understands the concerns of ordinary people.No surprise that in one poll the Tories have opened a four-point lead over Corbyn’s Labour.After a short summer break following our fantastic World Cup, it is great to have the beautiful game back.We’ve already witnessed breathtaking goals, crunching tackles and some blinding saves.And there is nowhere better to get the best football coverage than inside Britain’s favourite newspaper.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: girlfriend magaluf lad forgives him
story: Alun Griffiths, 27, was touching down on the Spanish resort with his mate when he got a text from partner Sarah Meah telling him tea was ready.But Sarah has revealed she wasnt angry with her boyfriend over the quick trip - and instead simply wanted him to take her away for another holiday.Speaking to the Sun Online, nurse Sarah, 36, said: I was at work while the boys were living it up in Spain and I was getting all the updates to my phone.Alun had gone out for after work drinks on Tuesday with pal Nigel Lewis when the spontaneous trip was born, with the pair travelling 30 miles to Cardiff Airport before jumping on the first flight to Magaluf.The friends arrived at 2am - heading straight for the bars before deciding to sleep on the beach when they realised they didnt have any accommodation booked.Railway site manager Alun said: My battery was dead when I woke up we were being chased off a private beach by security guards.With nowhere better to go we decided to start drinking again.Luckily we met a nice woman later in the day who used her phone to book us into a hotel so we could have a shower.We went out again that night but two days on the sesh was enough for me. Thats when I called Sarah and asked her to book me a flight home.Alun revealed that Sarah wasnt best pleased when she first wound out what happened - but had since made him promise her a trip to Amsterdam as pay back.He said: She calls me out but our rows are always in good spirit.She text back saying You are winding me up, what an idiot.But finished off telling me to have a good time.The playful dad said Sarah wasnt a nagging girlfriend, adding: But she has said Ive got to take her away now to make up for it so we are looking at a trip to Amsterdam.Hopefully this time I can give my boss a bit more notice.It was thanks to Sarah that the pair managed to get home - booking the pair the first flight back.Sarah said: The best part is that I had to rescue the boys and get them a flight home when theyd had enough.People have messaged me saying Im a mug for forgiving him but there was no fall out.Its all been a big laugh and Im just glad he was safe and they stuck together even if they did go a bit too wild.The couple have been best mates for nearly three years and only recently took their relationship to the next level.They have now been seeing each other for 8 weeks and live around the corner from each other on the Gurnos estate in Merthyr Tydfil, South Wales.Dad-of-four Alun said: We love the banter, its one of the reasons we are great together. We are mates first. Its great she can take a joke and accepts my wild ways.

title: pm faces revolt rail fare hikes
story: Livid backbenchers said a “fare freeze” was the minimum the Government should do for passengers who have suffered on Southern and Northern Rail this year.Conservative backbencher Tim Loughton said a rumoured 3.5 per cent ticket price increase would “go beyond adding insult to injury”.He told The Sun: “A fare rise would be absolutely outrageous. In any other customer facing industry we’d be looking at proper refunds.”And Treasury aide Chris Philp insisted Transport Secretary Chris Grayling had to deliver on plans announced in June to give commuters on Southern a month’s worth of compensation.He said: “No one who has suffered should be paying more next year. People have paid for a service and it’s not been received.”Labour demanded a fare freeze on Sunday – and called for a windfall tax on train operators.Official inflation figures tomorrow are due to show retail prices rose by 3.5 per cent in July. The July figure is taken as the basis for annual fare hikes in January.A 3.5 per cent rise would push up season tickets for between London and Ashford by £188 to £5,567, London and Southampton by £200 to £5,902. A season ticket from Macclesfield to Manchester on troubled Northern Rail would also rise by £90 to £2,663.The hikes come after a summer marked by timetabling chaos and cancelled services across the country.Southern has warned passengers this week they face 34 days of disruption on the Brighton to London mainline from September due to “improvement” works. Fares across the UK have soared by 40 per cent over the past decade.The Department for Transport yesterday said that while further hikes were “unwelcome” they were essential to funding work on the railways. But Tories have urged the Government to follow ex-Chancellor George Osborne – who capped regulated rail fares in 2011.Insiders argue that unions must share part of the blame for soaring ticket prices as around 25p in every £1 spent goes on wages. Labour’s former Transport Secretary Andrew Adonis said customer dissatisfaction was running at levels that would “shame” the likes of major supermarkets.He stormed: “Watchdogs Which? say that one in five rail passengers are dissatisfied with their last journey. Imagine that was a supermarket, with one in five dissatisfied with the last food they bought. Passengers shouldn’t be expected to pay more for worse.”After a disastrous year, there is no other industry that would turn round and ask customers for even more.The failure of the Government to take responsibility, blaming unions or claiming the cash is for “investment”, is simply not good enough. It’s the same as last year’s excuse.It is time for a radical overhaul — but that does not mean nationalisation. Far from it. Our railways need MORE private sector involvement.The hybrid system we have, in which private operators rely on publicly owned tracks and have their fares regulated by government, has led us into the worst of both worlds.Transport supremo Chris Grayling needs to take on the unions once and for all. And he needs to introduce real competition on the railways, giving operators far more freedom.Commuters deserve better than finger-pointing and higher fares.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sajid javid non eu citizen migration loophole
story: Migration Watch said the number of multi-nationals exploiting inter-company transfers to bring in new recruits was up almost 25 per cent in the past decade.Inter-company transfers don’t count towards the cap on skilled non-EU workers – set at 20,700 a year.Migration Watch chair Andrew Green said: “Many people are asking why non-EU migration has not been reduced. Here is part of the answer.“Either the Government have taken their eye off the ball or they have been too heavily influenced by a small group of companies and have ignored their own.”Migration Watch said that since 1992, the number of ICTs (inter-company transfers) has increased eightfold. In 1997 the Home Office issued around 15,000 to workers and their families.This jumped to 47,000 in 2007 and 58,000 last year.Two types of ICTs can be issued – from long-term staff visas to permits for graduate trainees.Migration Watch’s blast comes just weeks after official figures revealed non-EU immigration pushed net migration to nearly 300,000 in the first full year since the Brexit referendum.Net migration from EU nations fell to just over 100,000 in 2017 – the lowest level in five years. But the highest number of people came to the UK from outside the bloc for 13 years.  Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mike ashley vows to save majority house of fraser
story: In his first interview since his Sports Direct firm bought the department store for £90million, the controversial owner of Newcastle United yesterday told The Sun he would try to keep 80 per cent of the 59 outlets open.So confident is he of achieving his target that he added: “In a year’s time you can hold my feet to the fire on that.”More than half were set for closure before Ashley, 53, took over last Friday — and he insisted there were brighter days ahead thanks to his ambitious vision to turn the 169-year-old chain into the Harrods of the high street.He explained: “In Harrods you get some exceptional services. What we would like to do is introduce a ‘concierge click and collect’ at House of Fraser.“When you go online and say you want to collect goods in-store, you should be able to book a time, book a changing room and book a stylist.“You get that kind of personal shopping service in a Harrods. There’s no reason why it couldn’t be rolled out nationally across House of Fraser.”Sports Direct, which already held an 11 per cent stake, bought House of Fraser outright just hours after it went into administration.It was left on the brink of collapse after the Chinese owner of toy store Hamleys pulled out of a £70million rescue deal.House of Fraser, which its new owner affectionately calls “HoF”, employs 17,000, including 11,500 in-store concession staff.Ashley, who is worth around £3billion, believes the key to securing its future is to introduce more luxury brands.He added that big-hitters such as Gucci, Prada, Stone Island and Mallet footwear were “the biggest thing missing” as House of Fraser ran into the red.Drawing on his experience with designer chain Flannels, which is owned by Sports Direct, he intends to stock House of Fraser with successful “cool brands of the moment”.He said: “We think the biggest and most important thing House of Fraser is missing is luxury brands. We think it will make a big difference.“It is not taking away from House of Fraser, but adding to it.“If you get the right product, it is not on the shelves for long.”Larger House of Fraser stores, such as the one in Birmingham, could see whole floors turned over to Sports Direct or Flannels, Ashley added.Among the stores that could be saved from closure is the Oxford Street flagship in London — if landlords and suppliers can be won over.Ashley admitted that landlords have been “battered and bruised” by a raft of retail tenants seeking rent reductions this year.In a message to them, he said: “Give us a chance and we will try to keep as many open as we can. We are here to get House of Fraser back to where it once was.”However, some analysts are sceptical that the colourful billionaire can pull it off.Independent retail analyst Nick Bubb warned: “It is far from clear if he really knows what he has taken on.”HOUSE OF FRASER lost its way but Ashley wants to take it upmarket with more luxury bestsellers, brands popular with younger customers and a personal shopper service.SPORTS DIRECT’s superstores are full of popular brands, including Lonsdale and Donnay. Dozens more outlets are planned as Ashley bids to turn it into the “Selfridges of sport”.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brit henna tattoo scar friday night dinner quote
story: Beth Fitzimmons was with eight pals on the Greek island of Zante when they decided to have the words Shalom Jackie inked on them for a laugh last month.But the 18-year-old, from Southwell, Nottinghamshire, had an allergic reaction to an ingredient in the black henna, which can contain high levels of toxic chemical paraphenylenediamine (PPD).Doctors reckon shell be left with the words scarred on her forearm for at least six months.They chose the phrase from the popular Channel 4 comedy series because people on holiday kept shouting it and she and her friends found it amusing.She said the group were on their third night out of the holiday when they decided to get the five euro henna tattoo done - but it wasnt until around a week later that it began to itch and feel like a burn.Beth said: We were on a night out but I dont really drink so I was sober when I did it.It was done by a random family in the street. The mum and dad were doing them.We woke up the next day and thought it was hilarious. We sent pictures to our parents and and they were like that better not be permanent.It was absolutely fine until about eight days later then it was so itchy and it felt like it was burning.It was so red. It was all raised up. Now it looks a bit like eczema and is very dry.She went to a pharmacy when she got back to the UK and was told to go to a walk-in centre.Beth, who is taking a gap year after finishing her A-Levels this summer, added: I thought that was a bit extreme so I went to the doctor on the Monday.I said to them that I was probably overreacting but I needed to know if it was going to scar permanently because when I looked it up it said you needed to be treated for chemical burns.I was so worried it would scar me forever.The doctors told me Id had an allergic reaction to it and it would take about six months to go completely.Beth was prescribed a steroid cream and told that due to the chemicals in black henna also being used in hair dyes, she would no longer be able to dye her hair.She added: She [the pharmacist] was very firm on it because she said my body would start attacking whats in the hair dye and that I could actually die.That was the worst thing for me - not being able to dye my hair.Beth says everyone was shouting the phrase made popular by the character Jim on the show, which is about two brothers who return home for dinner with their parents every Friday night.Beth said: I love the show - its hilarious. Friday Night Dinner seems to be the thing that young people are obsessed with at the moment.It was everywhere in Zante. People would shout different lines back at each other.Warning others against the dangers, Beth said: I would 100 per cent say do not get black henna. If I would have known before I wouldnt have done it. It was a case of blind ignorance.

title: damian green ni hike 40s
story: The former Cabinet Minister made a fresh bid for middle-aged workers to pay hundreds more in tax every year in a newspaper interview.Asked how he’d fund a multi-billion shortfall in elderly care, he said: “In two ways: with an increase in national insurance for the over-40s, and the use of a small proportion of the housing wealth of the over-65s.”Mr Green added: “We have a system which assumes you retire in your early sixties and then live for a few years. That’s not true. Many more people are going to live until they are 90.“Practically a third of your life will be lived in what we used to term retirement.And it’s not sustainable economically and it’s not sustainable personally either.”Mr Green was forced to resign late last year over claims of inappropriate behaviour and pornography on a Commons computer.Before that he was invloved in a review of social care for the elderly in Britain - branded the UK’s ticking time bomb.Health Secretary Matt Hancock will unveil his own proposals to tackle the spending shortfall later this year.It followed the Conservative’s lead balloon manifesto policy that meant people with assets of £100,000 or more would have to pay for their own care.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: tory new brexit plan next month
story: Arch-Brexiteers want to deliver a vision for an “alternative to Chequers” just days before a critical Tory party conference.Eurosceptics are incensed by the PM’s Chequers proposal - claiming a bid to stay in a single market for goods will tie the UK to EU rules for years to come.The plans are believed to have the support of Jacob Rees-Mogg, head of the Tory MPs ‘European Research Group’.Ex-Cabinet Minister Peter Lilley and John Redwood are looking at tariffs and trade options. It will put intense pressure on No.10 in the run-up to a party conference that could decide her fate.One source told The Sun: “This is about delivering the clean Brexit that people voted for. No concessions.”The revelation came as Tory party bigwigs sparked backlash by urging local associations to back the PM’s Chequers plan on the doorstep.Conservative HQ was branded “moronic” by Eurosceptic MPs after asking regional branches to spend a small fortune on leaflets backing the PM’s soft Brexit plan.Maria Caulfield, who quit as vice-chair of the Tory Party over Chequers, said local officers and councillors were furious. Posting on a Tory Whatsapp group she stormed: “Are the power that be determined to add insult to injury after the white paper, Boris, the PM letter and now this.”Marcus Fysh, a Eurosceptic who has called for the PM to go, added: “Uttterly moronic I’m afraid. The sooner this administration is changed the better.”They also hit out over the “Lib Dem Yellow” colour of the mailout – which explains how the Chequers proposal will end free movement, and the rule of the European Court of Justice.Brexit backers argue the PM’s plan to keep Britain in a single market for goods will force the UK to be subject to ECJ rulings for years. title: the sun reader letters boris burka
story: But there has been a groundswell of support for BoJo from ordinary people, fed up at what they see as attacks on freedom of expression and the British way of life.This is what Sun readers have to say about the issue, and Brexit-backer Boris:BORIS Johnson has a dig at burka-wearing Muslims and our elite shake with fear. Don’t they know many thousands of people agree with him? Or do they chose to again ignore the people of this country? Any movement on Boris from the out-of-touch Government will cost them dear.SO Dominic Grieve has threatened to quit Parliament if Boris Johnson became PM. I can think of no better reason for wishing him success.BANG on Boris, about the burka. It being worn in public is scary for children who see it.FREEDOM of speech must not be compromised – and there can be no question of legal action being taken against Boris Johnson, it would be prejudiced by all the attacks on him.THIS week it has been especially hard to be a Muslim woman. Apparently I am not getting the joke, I’m over sensitive, bullied, oppressed, unintegrated, politically motivated, dividing Britain – this list goes on. Perhaps Boris Johnson’s Etonian education did not enable him to understand that in polite society it’s rude to comment with ridicule on the way people dress.ONE thing critics of Boris Johnson’s burka comment overlook is the impact of burka-wearers on those who are deaf and rely on seeing facial expressions, and lip-reading.THE do-gooders complaining about Boris are fanning the flames of hatred by highlighting issues that one wouldn’t really think about. Talk about “integration” appears to be one-sided and discriminatory towards the indigenous people. There is some equilibrium lacking in our “fair, just and equal” land of ours.WHILE I am not sure Boris used a good choice of words likening women in burkas to pillar boxes, he was right that we are frightened by what it represents. We must not destroy Boris, he is good for the people of this country, he cares. He must also be allowed to speak honestly, he has nothing to apologise for.LIGHTEN up, Boris spoke the thoughts of many millions of Brits. If making a gaffe was against the law, Prince Philip could have been banged up in the Tower of London on many occasions during the last 50 years. He wrote the book on it.Boris might have an agenda – what politician doesn’t? – but this mustn’t mean people don’t have a right to voice criticism. Face veils in public, and burkas, are not religious requirements and we must have the right to criticise the wearers.IF I was Boris Johnson, I would agree to attend the diversity training some have suggested . . . and then tear the training session to pieces.I SAW Ranvir Singh berating her guests on morning TV for daring to agree with Boris Johnson? I wonder what her bosses would say if she suggested that she presented her programme wearing a burka. I think we all know the answer to that.PHIL GROWDENNOTHING Theresa May says can be taken at face value. Not so long ago, she promised to stop the witch-hunt of British soldiers, who have seen action and survived in many parts of the world. However, the victimisation of our veterans continues unabated. They are now joined by Boris Johnson, who has frequently ignited the Prime Minister’s wrath and must therefore, be thrown to the wolves.A BUS company has apologised after a driver told a woman to remove her niqab. So would a bank apologise if a security guard asked a man to remove his ski mask?HOW would I stand as a Christian male finding a Muslim lady, dressed in a burka, having a heart attack? Would I be allowed to remove her veil to perform mouth-to-mouth?THE controversy surrounding Boris Johnson’s burka comments has reached ridiculous heights. Police conducting an investigation. Really?IF Theresa May had the guts to ban the burka like a lot of other countries, we might not be having this discussion about what Boris Johnson said.SOMETHING featureless with a rectangular hole in it can resemble a letter box, there’s probably one on your front door, go and have a look. It has also been known for the person inside to be a terrorist, not an innocent woman. Stop being so pathetic, have a sense of humour, act like adultsI READ about a motorcyclist at a filling station having to remove his crash helmet while a woman (who could have been a criminal’s getaway driver) filling up at the pump next to him was wearing a burka. Meanwhile Boris’s remarks are causing hysteria.I HAVE been visiting garden centres and supermarket car parks in my car, which is bedecked with Brexit stickers, asking many people their opinion on the Boris situation. For Boris, I find there is a great deal of love out there. For the Chequers “deal” there is none.IT’S true that Boris Johnson has used strong language but Muslim terrorists are doing far worse things than robbing banks, by committing terrorist atrocities. It would be a sad day when the Muslim community can’t take such a comment, especially when many Muslim women, in my view, do not want this clothing themselves.IT’S confirmed, lunatics are ruining the country. We have the enemy (EU) knocking art the door and all the idiots can find to discuss is Boris Johnson’s perfectly fair comment. If it wasn’t so serious it would be funny. Brexit should be top of the agenda.THERE are easily as many people who agree with BoJo’s comments as those who don’t. So why is it those who don’t will instigate an investigation, leaving those who do without a voice? Even senior Muslims and imams have said that the burka is not a requirement in Islam, so why is it we only tend to listen to those who are offended?Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: the last leg ally ross
story: You expect this reaction, obviously, from news organisations who have to fill endless blank hours with something during silly season.The really depressing thing, though, was that a late-night Channel 4 “comedy” show and its presenters were the most outraged of them all.I’m talking, of course, about The Last Leg which, for reasons that still escape me, genuinely fancies itself as one of television’s edgiest and funniest shows.It’s not, clearly. The Last Leg is a television safe space, the authentic voice of the PC establishment and as predictable as the sun rising in the morning.So you knew, long before Friday’s transmission, that they’d be targeting Boris, who is a thousand times funnier and edgier than anyone on this show, in his own way.Nearly a whole working week host Adam Hills and his two mates had to prepare some decent material as well, and this was the best three professional comedians could do.Alex Brooker: “The burka is an item of clothing worn by a human being, the other is a postbox, you f***ing idiot.”Adam Hills: “I’d much rather sit next to a person in burka than a p***k in a suit.”Josh Widdicombe: “Theresa May has only just realised Boris is a t**t, so she should apologise as well.”On and on it went, for 12 minutes and 54 seconds, a figure I mention because I’ve had the clock on this lot, and if you want to know exactly how much of a toss they really give about religious sensitivities then it’s best measured by the fact this series of The Last Leg has devoted just 65 hand-wringing seconds to the anti-Semitic poison infecting the Labour Party.It was crammed hurriedly into the previous episode, which was worth watching just to see Adam Hills describe Corbyn’s handling of this crisis as “a faux pas”, (which isn’t French for “shameful cluster-f***”) and the C4 audience react with evident discomfort because he’d drawn attention to the Labour leader’s failings and, therefore, broken one of comedy’s secret and golden rules.If you doubted these rules exist, incidentally, then ever the virtue-signalling fool, Adam Hills was good enough to spell them out for us on Friday.“Every religion should be open to ridicule . . . but you kind of need to be in the club.“Alex and I can make jokes about disabilities as we’re technically disabled.”Boris, he then explained, can’t make jokes about burkas, ’cos he’s “a white Etonian”, nor could comedy giant Rowan Atkinson defend him, as he was “a white man who lives in Oxford and drives an F1 car”.Even if we ignore the fact he’s assumed that all Muslims are black, something pretty staggering is going on here.For Mary Whitehouse, in all her pearl-clutching glory, never imagined anything quite as Draconian and controlling as this form of satirical Apartheid.Adam Hills has a point, though, when he uses the word “club”. That’s exactly what television comedy has become.A closed, left-wing shop where you don’t even bother joining the audience unless you follow the rigid “Tories and Brexit are evil” party line.This is not creating comedy, it’s policing it, and also the reason why applause has replaced laughter on all those Channel 4 and BBC news satires which have failed to realise there is only one simple rule to be observed when creating these shows: Make it funny, dumbo.I would suggest, at this point, Adam Hills gets off his moral high horse, for once, and gives this “funny” idea a go.But then I could also ask Boris to have a crack at anchoring the British women’s 4x100m relay team to gold at the next Olympics, wearing a burka, and I’d know there was only the remotest chance of one ever happening.Run Boris, run.MEANWHILE, back on Channel 4’s Meet The Drug Lords: Inside The Real Narcos, Jason “Foxy” Fox was with the Colombian navy this week and desperate for a look inside one of the incredible home-made submarines they’d confiscated from drug-smugglers.“Is it locked?”“Yes.”And there’ll be more Bafta-worthy action from Foxy and his forward-planning department this week, I’m sure.EVER since it discovered that Danny Dyer was the rightful heir to the English throne, Who Do You Think You Are? has been struggling to find a purpose, or indeed a celebrity, who could see the bigger picture.That special someone who would acknowledge history’s great events with more than a few “wows” and shrugs and not think their own career made all of their ancestors’ suffering worthwhile.Finally, last night, they found him.Judge Robert Rinder, who as well as having the best brain at ITV (Luna the Labrador off This Morning has the second best) also turns out to be a natural television journalist, telling the story of his maternal great-grandfather, Israel, and his beloved grandfather, Morris, simply, beautifully and without ever letting the details overwhelm him.The former fled revolutionary Latvia at the turn of the last century.The latter’s entire family was wiped out in Treblinka’s gas chambers.Yet he somehow survived the Buchen-wald, Theresienstadt and Schlieben concentration camps and made it to Britain, which offered him salvation, friendship, justice and, above all, a sense that “life is worth living” that has been passed down through eternally grateful generations.It’s a remarkable story, so if you missed it, try to catch tonight’s repeat (BBC1, 11.25pm).SCENES and characters the viewers are unlikely to forget in a hurry on the final episode of BBC2’s wonderful Travels In Trumpland With Ed Balls.First stop, the President’s Mar-a-Lago compound in Florida, where Ed spent the most uncomfortable night of his life, since Strictly, at a one-year-in-office party for Trump, with Toni Holt Kramer and a group of fans who were called The Trumpettes, but could well have been the provisional wing of The Golden Girls.If you thought they were a bit sinister, though, he was then off squirrel hunting in the forests of Georgia with two hillbillies who might not have been plucking banjos but they certainly had the mad cackling laughs and slightly unsettling line in hospitality.“Are you ready to be a man today, Ed?” asked one, as you began to wonder if he could escape with his dignity intact, let alone blend in with the local gene pool.Then he suddenly reappeared – and this was a masterstroke – wearing a Norwich City scarf.Scrub everything I ever said about Ed Balls.The man’s a diplomatic genius.Sent in by Rob Milner, East Yorkshire. Picture research: Alfie SnellingTHIS Morning, Wednesday:Gok Wan: “Coming up, Ninja nanas, in a minute, John Torode’s in the Lake District at 11.45, and we’ve got the return of the Hawaiian shirt at midday.“First, would you like to live ten years longer?”Ten years? title: dad blames size nineteen feet for job woes as he cant find shoes big enough for job interviews
story: David Henderson, 39, can’t find smart black shoes that fit so he turns up to job interviews in his enormous white Adidas trainers — the only footwear he can get into.He says he’s been stuck on benefits for almost a decade as interviewers don’t take him seriously because of his get-up.And to add to his woes, cruel strangers mock him in the street with taunts like “clown shoes” and “Sideshow Bob”.The fed-up former security guard searched Scotland for a cobbler who would make him bespoke shoes but drew a blank.He extended his enquiries across the UK and found a London firm who could help.But to his horror they quoted him a price of £1,500 — far beyond his means as his Universal Credit payment leaves him just £40 to spend each month after bills.A pair of size 19 leather brogues could cost as much as an eye-watering £2,000.Now he’s going public with his problem in the hope it will help him find some decent shoes and get him off the dole.David, from Methil, Fife, said last night: “My feet have just got wider over time and doctors don’t know why.“Employers don’t believe me when I say I can’t buy black shoes but it’s impossible to find affordable ones in my size.“Some interviewers are bemused when I tell them why I’m not wearing black shoes.“Some are surprised and some are sympathetic. But I can tell some of them are thinking ‘are you for real?’“I feel like a bit of a tink turning up to job interviews wearing a tracksuit, T-shirt and trainers — but I would look ridiculous if I was wearing smart clothes and my big white trainers.”David added: “It’s been a total nightmare and very embarrassing. I feel like I have tried everywhere in Scotland but nobody does my size.“And I get people making fun of me when I’m at the bus stop or walking down the street people say ‘Wow. look at him. Are those boats on your feet?’. Others call me ‘banana feet’.It’s demoralising. I think I’d have a job if I had shoes. It brings me down and it’s pretty hurtful.“I just want to get back to work. I can’t be the only person in the UK with size 19 feet.”David, who is 6ft 2in tall and weighs in at 24 stone, has had big feet since he was youngster.When he left school he was a size 16. But he could find shoes that fitted him at the time and worked in retail, cleaning and security jobs through his 20s.But since then his feet have grown three sizes and are almost 12in long and 7in wide. David says he has been turned down by at least ten employers since he last worked.His worried girlfriend Annie Jones, 32, said she hopes he can resolve the situation and land a job.Annie said: “People laugh at him. They point at him and call him names. It’s mean when they call him “clown shoes” and it gets him down.I hope he can get back to work. It would mean a lot to him.”Do you have bigger feet? title: first part time jobs sun writers
story: The number of 16 to 17-year-olds taking part-time jobs has more than halved since 1997, dropping from 42 per cent to 18 per cent. It means young people are missing out on essential skills as they approach adulthood.GRANT ROLLINGS asked five Sun columnists what their first part-time jobs were and the valuable lessons they learned – from being polite to skiving.I ALWAYS had a summer job, usually it meant working full-time hours on my normal Saturday job as holiday cover. This was either in a boutique such as Chelsea Girl or in BHS, where I worked on the sweetie counter.I coped with the boredom by sneakily munching on the best chocolate sweets from the pick-and-mix. I also worked as a waitress in a trendy Glasgow eaterie during the holidays.All of these jobs gave me the most enormous respect for the men and women who toil for long hours, often dealing with unreasonable members of the public for too little pay and not much prospect of promotion.Working in the service industry taught me the power of a disarming smile, and proved that my old granny’s saying that “you get more in life from sugar than vinegar” could not be more true.Grumpy customers demanding refunds and diners moaning that they had been waiting too long for their main course were usually placated with a swift apology and a promise to sort things out.A major restaurant blunder could often be smoothed over with a free coffee or pudding.MY favourite summer job came in 1977. I was a traffic enumerator for Middlesbrough Council. That meant I spent all day counting cars. All the way up one side of Linthorpe Road, all the way back down the other.I had to write down all the number plates. In the end, I got a bit bored and spent the time hanging out at my mate’s T-shirt shop or Fearnley Records and made the numbers up, always remembering to have them end in the local codes of HN or (I think) XG. I hope the council thought it worthwhile.It was better than the glue factory, where I’d been very briefly working on a weighbridge. Foreman pressed a button and this vast door opened and thousands of rotting animal carcasses fell out. I can still smell it now, all these years later. I passed out — soft lad, you see.Or there was working the nightshift pricing cans of food and stuff in Hintons, the local convenience store. Every time I turned up, the manager would say, ‘Here he is, the poor man’s Rod Stewart’.A friend of mine, Mark, had a much better summer job.He was a Club 18-30 holiday rep. He shagged 21 girls in 25 days, which gave me my first story to sell to the national newspapers.MY first holiday job was in the summer of 1985 when I was 16 years old. I had already been turned down from working at Waitrose in Enfield Town on the basis I was “too glamorous”.That just goes to show how far we have come in such a short time. I have never set foot in a Waitrose since that day because I was beyond furious. Anyway, the job I did get was working in a hairdresser’s on Goodge Street in London.My journey involved three changes and about 14 stops every day. The job was meant to be answering the phone, sweeping up and generally helping out, but before the end of the first week I was running the till, the appointment system, cashing up and generally managing the place.The only thing I could not do was cut hair, but that didn’t stop me cutting my friends’ hair — with very mixed results, more bad than good — on the basis I worked in a hairdresser’s so they thought I should. I remember the liberating feeling of earning my own money, it gave me the greatest sense of independence, self-esteem and self-belief.I worked out I was actually good in a work environment, talking to people — for example, talking women into perms they didn’t want — being responsible, handling money and making a difference to my employer.The biggest transition we make in our lives is leaving education to go into the workplace, and summer jobs prepare you for this.I HAD dozens of summer jobs, from working as a scaffolder’s mate with a convicted murderer, who kept a pistol in the glove compartment of his Ford Escort, to donning a white suit and Geiger counter to carry out maintenance on the core of the main reactor at a nuclear power station.I learned a hundred things from each and every job, but it was working as a grocery assistant at my local supermarket that had the most impact.My best friend and I both got jobs there at the same time. He was a star performer at school, a brilliant academic, but he couldn’t take the pace and got fired after a couple of months.It was incredibly hard, repetitive work.The manager was an ex-Army major — very strict on haircuts, discipline and stealing.There was always the prospect of the Tannoy announcement “customer service one hundred”, which was code for a shoplifter having been spotted.All the male floor staff were required to assemble at till number one to tackle the suspect, who would sometimes become violent.I was much happier making the cheese look pretty and eventually became the ruler of the entire soft dairy aisle — a project I’m still working on.I WAS 13 in Brownes Wine bar, Stafford Street, Derby, summer 1987, some years before it burned down in mysterious circumstances (has a bar ever burnt down innocently?). I was chief bottler-up.This involved the soul-sapping exercise of sifting through bins taller than me for all the recyclable bottles from the previous night’s festivities and putting them in their correct crates. This took all morning and you ended up cut to shreds and stinking of Britvic and Schlitz.I was then asked to be the cook — this involved microwaving lasagne for drunk people. I was paid the princely sum of £3 per hour. I realised how crap this was, so one scorching Saturday I nicked the shampoo that came with my dad’s company car and took advantage of the sketchy Eighties attitude to drink-driving and washed all the customers’ cars in the car park for a fiver a pop.I literally cleaned up. It was the greatest Dragons’ Den moment I’ve ever had. I waxed on and off all day, rinsing my dad of his prized BMW product. He arrived to pick me up and I was minted. A 13-year-old with £64 in his pocket. That coveted Swatch would finally be mine.He then told me the dog had been run over, so that’s another memory ruined.Thanks for reminding me.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: corbyn is unfit to be labour leader
story: His entire political career has been spent in close company with anti- Semites, terrorist sympathisers and extremists.So it shouldn’t be a surprise that he was pictured appearing to pay his respects to Black September, the terror group which murdered 11 Israelis and one German policeman at the Munich Olympics.That’s a group that not only killed in cold blood but tortured and brutalised their victims too.It is genuinely shocking that the Leader of the Opposition is so willing to lie about it. To say that he was “present but not involved” is an insult to voters’ intelligence when photographs show him holding a wreath and gurning for a nearby camera.To allow his press office to say the widows of those murdered in Munich were being “misled” is, even among the many shameful episodes we’ve seen since he became Labour leader three hate-filled years ago, disgraceful.The most vital qualification for power in this country must be integrity. And Jeremy Corbyn has demonstrated this week that he has absolutely none of it.But for all of the shame that he brings upon Labour, it is nothing compared to the spinelessness of the party’s “moderate” MPs whose opposition to Corbyn extends not much further than wishy-washy tweets.“Present but not involved” isn’t an excuse for Corbyn but nor is it for the cowards on Labour’s backbenches.Corbyn cannot be allowed near government. But the rest of the party has lost the public’s faith too.TOMORROW, official figures are likely to suggest that train fares will go up by another 3.5 per cent in January.If you’re a commuter who has put up with delayed and cancelled trains, you’ll be wondering what you’re paying for.After a disastrous year, there is no other industry that would turn round and ask customers for even more.The failure of the Government to take responsibility, blaming unions or claiming the cash is for “investment”, is simply not good enough. It’s the same as last year’s excuse.It is time for a radical overhaul — but that does not mean nationalisation. Far from it. Our railways need MORE private sector involvement.The hybrid system we have, in which private operators rely on publicly owned tracks and have their fares regulated by government, has led us into the worst of both worlds.Transport supremo Chris Grayling needs to take on the unions once and for all. And he needs to introduce real competition on the railways, giving operators far more freedom.Commuters deserve better than finger-pointing and higher fares.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
